metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Singhara Singh, Bir Singh and Tega Singh

facts.text: On March 20, 1959, Raja Ram, a shopkeeper of Afzalgarh in Uttar Pradesh, was murdered by gunshot in his shop.
Seven persons including respondents Singhara Singh, Bir Singh and Tega Singh prosecuted for the murder.

Additional Sessions Judge of Bijnor convicted Singhara Singh under S.302 IPC (death), Bir Singh and Tega Singh under S.302 r/w 120B,109,114 IPC (Bir Singh death, Tega Singh life imprisonment), acquitted others.
Respondents appealed to Allahabad High Court, State appealed acquittals, Reference No.142/1960 for confirmation of death sentences.
High Court allowed respondents' appeals, dismissed State's appeal, rejected reference, acquitted respondents.
State filed appeal by special leave to Supreme Court, leave granted only qua three respondents.
Confessions of guilt purportedly recorded by Mr. Dixit, a second class magistrate, under S.164 CrPC.
Prosecution unable to prove Mr. Dixit specially empowered under S.164 by State Government.
Records not admissible under Evidence Act ss.74,80 as not recorded under S.164.
Prosecution called Mr. Dixit to prove confessions orally, using record to refresh memory under S.159 Evidence Act.
If oral evidence inadmissible, no other evidence to convict respondents.

legal_issues.text: Admissibility of oral evidence by a second class magistrate (not specially empowered under S.164 CrPC) of confessions purportedly recorded by him under S.164 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Nazir Ahmed v. King Emperor wrongly decided; principle from Taylor v. Taylor not applicable as S.164 provisions not mandatory per S.533 CrPC.
S.164 only for benefit of ss.74,80 Evidence Act; non-compliance deprives prosecution of that but allows oral proof.
Nazir Ahmed distinguishable: applies only to empowered magistrates; unempowered magistrate's oral evidence admissible as under general law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Nazir Ahmed v. King Emperor; Ashrafi v. State

respondent_arguments.text: Present case governed by Nazir Ahmed; oral evidence inadmissible even if magistrate not empowered.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Nazir Ahmed v. King Emperor; S.164 CrPC

court_reasoning.text: Principle from Taylor v. Taylor applies: power under S.164 to be exercised only in prescribed manner or not at all; oral evidence prohibited to protect safeguards.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.164 by implication prohibits magistrate from giving oral evidence of confessions.

court_reasoning.text: S.533 allows oral evidence only to prove compliance with S.164 procedure when record defective; emphasizes procedure mandatory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.533 does not make S.164 directory.

court_reasoning.text: Object of S.164 is safeguards for accused, not just prosecution convenience; oral evidence would bypass safeguards.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nazir Ahmed correctly decided and followed in Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh and Deep Chand.

court_reasoning.text: Principle applies even to unempowered magistrate: power conferred only on specified classes; no anomaly in prohibiting oral evidence.
Distinguishes Ashrafi (identification parade, obiter on S.164), Ghulam Hussain (relevancy under Evidence Act), Emperor v. Ram Naresh (voluntary petition, not S.164).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited cases do not permit oral evidence here.

holdings.text: Oral evidence of confession by magistrate purporting to record under S.164 CrPC inadmissible, whether empowered or not.

precedents_cited.relevance: Oral evidence inadmissible if S.164 procedure not followed; applies to unempowered magistrates too.
Dealt with identification parades; obiter on S.164 not accepted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh v. State of Vindhya Pradesh
Deep Chand v. State of Rajasthan

precedents_cited.relevance: Power given in certain way must be exercised that way or not at all.
Relevancy of S.164 statements under Evidence Act, not proof.
Voluntary petition admitted under S.21 Evidence Act, not S.164.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Convictions under these for murder and abetment.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Recording confessions; admissibility if procedure not followed.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Proof of public documents; refreshing memory; admissions.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's rejection of oral evidence of confessions, affirmed acquittal of respondents as no other evidence sufficient for conviction.

key_quotes.text: "where a power is given to do a certain thing in a certain way, the thing must be done in that way or not at all and that other methods of performance are necessarily forbidden"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle from Taylor v. Taylor applied to S.164.

key_quotes.text: A confession duly recorded under s. 164 would no doubt be a public document under s. 74 of the Evidence Act which would prove itself under s. 80 of that Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why records are preferred but oral proof barred.

key_quotes.text: We think that the High Court in the present case rightly rejected the oral evidence of Mr. Dixit.
key_quotes.speaker: court
